author: Nistula Hebbar
text:
At a meeting of constituents of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) and BJP president Amit Shah this week, one of the issues that came up for discussion was the government’s shift in stand on minority status to Aligarh Muslim University and Jamia Millia Islamia. Lok Janshakti Party leader Ram Vilas Paswan termed the government’s stand “discomforting and an unnecessary controversy.”

The Union government on January 11 this year, changed its affidavit in a case challenging the minority status of AMU and JMI to say that the two universities could not be granted that status as they had been set up by Parliament.

Mr. Paswan raised this issue during the dinner meeting held for NDA allies at Parliamentary Affairs Minister M. Venkaiah Naidu’s residence in the presence of Mr. Shah. According to sources, “Mr. Paswan said these were established institutions and the government’s shift in stand may also infringe on the right of State governments.”

At this, Mr. Shah said the Centre was proceeding as per sound legal advice and there was enough to support the Centre’s affidavit.

Mr. Paswan said the controversy could snowball as there were many minority institutions in the country, including several prominent ones in Delhi like the St. Stephen’s College and the Khalsa College.

According to sources present at this meeting, SAD leader Sukhbir Badal supported Mr. Paswan’s contention that the move could open a can of worms.
title: NDA constituents unhappy over AMU, Jamia issue
